summary: This is an October 2, 2020 internal update from the Public Corruption Unit, summarizing significant developments in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It details her indictment and arrest, the ongoing investigation into Epstein's co-conspirators, evidence against Maxwell and an unnamed assistant, discovery production, and efforts to interview Prince Andrew.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Indicted for her role in facilitating Jeffrey Epstein's abuse of minor girls, arrested in New Hampshire, and detained. Described as a co-conspirator who groomed victims and participated in abuse.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the abuse scheme; committed suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) on August 10, 2019. The investigation into his co-conspirators continues.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: The prosecution team is pursuing a potential interview with him, but his counsel declined a voluntary interview.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as Epstein's former girlfriend and a co-conspirator who groomed underage victims for him and participated in the abuse.
The document references one of Epstein's assistants who participated in scheduling, setting up rooms, photographing, and paying victims, implying a working relationship under Epstein and Maxwell.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein committed suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Indicted
events.description: A grand jury returned a six-count indictment charging Ghislaine Maxwell for her role in facilitating Epstein's abuse of minor girls.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Arrested
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested at a residence in New Hampshire.

events.title: Initial Discovery Production
events.description: The prosecution team made an initial discovery production in the Maxwell case.

keyFacts: The investigation into Epstein's co-conspirators was active and ongoing as of October 2020, with 'considerable evidence' developed against Ghislaine Maxwell.
Evidence implicated an unnamed assistant of Epstein's in scheduling 'massages,' setting up rooms, photographing victims, and paying victims in the early to mid-2000s.
The prosecution was actively pursuing an interview with Prince Andrew, but his counsel had declined a voluntary interview.
The prosecution team was working on a second discovery production of electronic materials and coordinating with the USAO-SDFL (Southern District of Florida) to review files for Brady/Giglio material.
Initial discussions were underway with counsel for an unnamed individual (likely the assistant) about the possibility of a felony disposition (plea deal).
